fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A meet, infimum, or greatest lower bound of a subset A\subseteq P in a preorder P is a greatest lower bound of A. We write \bigwedge {A}, or x\wedge y for \bigwedge \{x, y\}. The dual notion is join, supremum, or least upper bound, written \vee .
When P is considered as a category, a meet is a product and a join is a coproduct.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain theory

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
A subset A of a preorder (P, \leq ) is a lower set if it is downward closed, i.e., if for all a \in A and x \in P, if x\leq a, then x\in A. Dually, an upper set is upward closed.
A lower bound of a subset A\subseteq P of a preorder P is an element x\in P such that x\leq a for all a\in A. The dual notion is upper bound.
An element x\in P of a preorder P is minimal if, whenever y\leq x, then x\leq y. The dual notion is maximal.
A least element or bottom \bot of a preorder P is an element such that \bot \leq x for all x\in P. The dual notion is greatest element or top \top .
Equivalently, considering P as a category, \bot is a terminal object and \top is a initial object.

A meet, infimum, or greatest lower bound of a subset A\subseteq P in a preorder P is a greatest lower bound of A. We write \bigwedge {A}, or x\wedge y for \bigwedge \{x, y\}. The dual notion is join, supremum, or least upper bound, written \vee .
When P is considered as a category, a meet is a product and a join is a coproduct.
A poset is a preorder which is skeletal as a category; equivalently, this means its relation is additionally antisymmetric.
A meet-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary meets. Dually, a join-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary joins.
Some authors use semilattice to refer to this notion, using (e.g.) bounded semilattice or semilattice with \top for what we call merely semilattice.
As a category, a meet-pseudosemilattice is a cartesian poset.
A pseudolattice is a poset with all binary meets and joins; in particular, it is both a meet- and join-pseudosemilattice.
A meet-semilattice is a poset with all finite meets; in particular, it is a meet-pseudosemilattice with bottom. Dually, a join-semilattice is a poset with all finite joins.
Equivalently, a meet-semilattice is a posetal finitely complete category, while a join-semilattice is a posetal finitely cocomplete category.
A lattice is a poset with all finite meets and joins; in particular, it is both a meet- and join-semilattice.
Equivalently, it is a posetal bicartesian category.

A lattice (or, more generally, a pseudolattice) is distributive if joins distribute over meets or, equivalently, meets distribute over joins, i.e. if it satisfies either of the equivalent conditions x\wedge (y\vee z) = (x\wedge y)\vee (x\wedge z)\quad \text { and }\quad x\vee (y\wedge z) = (x\vee y)\wedge (x\vee z).
Equivalently, a distributive lattice is a posetal distributive category.
A complete lattice is a poset with all meets and joins; equivalently, it is complete and cocomplete as a category.

A Heyting algebra is a posetal bicartesian closed category. In particular, this means it has all finite meets and joins (is a lattice), along with an operation \Rightarrow , called implication, such that z\leq x\Rightarrow y\text { if and only if } z\wedge x\leq y.
A Boolean algebra is a distributive lattice in which every element x has a complement \lnot x satisfying x\wedge \lnot x = \bot \quad \text { and }\quad x\vee \lnot x = \top .
A frame is a distributive lattice with arbitrary joins and the infinitary distributive law x\wedge \bigvee y_i = \bigvee (x\wedge y_i).
A frame is a distributive lattice with arbitrary joins and the infinitary distributive law x\wedge \bigvee y_i = \bigvee (x\wedge y_i).

fr:title.text: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subobjects of a presheaf form a Heyting algebra

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {P} Set be a presheaf. Then the subobject poset of P is a Heyting algebra.

A Heyting algebra is a posetal bicartesian closed category. In particular, this means it has all finite meets and joins (is a lattice), along with an operation \Rightarrow , called implication, such that z\leq x\Rightarrow y\text { if and only if } z\wedge x\leq y.
A complete lattice is a poset with all meets and joins; equivalently, it is complete and cocomplete as a category.

A lattice (or, more generally, a pseudolattice) is distributive if joins distribute over meets or, equivalently, meets distribute over joins, i.e. if it satisfies either of the equivalent conditions x\wedge (y\vee z) = (x\wedge y)\vee (x\wedge z)\quad \text { and }\quad x\vee (y\wedge z) = (x\vee y)\wedge (x\vee z).
Equivalently, a distributive lattice is a posetal distributive category.
A lattice is a poset with all finite meets and joins; in particular, it is both a meet- and join-semilattice.
Equivalently, it is a posetal bicartesian category.
A pseudolattice is a poset with all binary meets and joins; in particular, it is both a meet- and join-pseudosemilattice.
A meet-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary meets. Dually, a join-pseudosemilattice is a poset with all binary joins.
Some authors use semilattice to refer to this notion, using (e.g.) bounded semilattice or semilattice with \top for what we call merely semilattice.
As a category, a meet-pseudosemilattice is a cartesian poset.
A meet-semilattice is a poset with all finite meets; in particular, it is a meet-pseudosemilattice with bottom. Dually, a join-semilattice is a poset with all finite joins.
Equivalently, a meet-semilattice is a posetal finitely complete category, while a join-semilattice is a posetal finitely cocomplete category.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.
A least element or bottom \bot of a preorder P is an element such that \bot \leq x for all x\in P. The dual notion is greatest element or top \top .
Equivalently, considering P as a category, \bot is a terminal object and \top is a initial object.
A lower bound of a subset A\subseteq P of a preorder P is an element x\in P such that x\leq a for all a\in A. The dual notion is upper bound.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A product is a limit of a discrete diagram. Its legs are called projections.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
